Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Effects of Water Contamination on Water Valuation in a Post-Disaster Context

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The fact that all life depends on water makes it one of the most vital substances on our planet, with populations across the world organizing ways to access the water they need to survive. At the same time, flood, drought, and contamination mark several ways that water can also pose a threat to life. Human activity -- such as mismanagement, travel, pollution, conflict, and widening social disparities -- can also contribute to water's potential danger, including the spread of deadly waterborne diseases. Sudden or otherwise dramatic disruptions in drinking-water quality expose important ways that humans value such an invaluable resource. To develop programs, policies, and infrastructure that ensure all Americans access to safe water, it is critical to understand not only the interacting human and environmental factors that lead to drinking-water contamination, but also the ways that individuals and societies adjust to water crises.

The new presence of cholera in Haiti provides an exemplary case through which to study the dynamic relationship between humans and water. Cholera is a waterborne disease that causes profuse diarrhea and possible death from rapid fluid loss. The investigators, who started traveling to Haiti in 2008, have been researching the cholera epidemic there since it began in 2010, nine months after the earthquake. The investigators' extensive understanding of the local context, robust network of contacts, and previous data with which to make comparisons will foster the successful implementation and impact of forthcoming research. The research will be conducted in the coastal city and surrounding rural areas of Saint-Marc, Haiti, near the mouth of the Artibonite River, which was contaminated with cholera bacteria in October 2010, sparking one of the largest cholera epidemics in recent history. Though preventable by drinking clean water and treatable with timely rehydration, and despite significant national and international investment in relief efforts, many Haitians remain vulnerable to infection. With the disease now endemic, the presence of cholera has likely prompted substantial changes in the political economy, management, and consumption of water in Haiti. Investigators will assess the extent to which drinking-water for many Haitians has gone from a trusted common resource to a market commodity, industrialized product, or privately administered good. They will also evaluate whether these changes, driven by local and international actors, are resulting in improved access to safe water, particularly among the poor. Based in Saint-Marc, investigators will conduct interviews, archival, and participant-based research, observe and participate in everyday life, shadow clinicians, water engineers, and water entrepreneurs, and collect quantitative data about water quality and household water use. Research findings about the ways disease, the environment, and human society influence one another will illuminate factors that promote, perpetuate, or protect against water insecurity, poverty, and illness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Haiti, a new surge of water products emerged in the wake of the nation’s first-ever cholera epidemic. Toxigenic Vibrio cholerae—a waterborne bacteria that causes sudden and life-threatening diarrhea—leaked from a United Nations military base into the Artibonite River in October 2010 and exploded throughout the country with devastating loss. The accelerating privatization of water resources in Haiti—and worldwide—accompanies a rising tide of anxiety about access to safe drinking-water, triggered by increasingly frequent threats of contamination and scarcity. Water commodities proliferate, but their consumption varies in ways not only economically determined. Our project also considers how emotions like fear and desire emerge in relation to and in relation with drinking-water.

 

Over the duration of this project award, Victoria Koski-Karell spent ten months engaging in doctoral dissertation research, including six months living and conducting fieldwork in the coastal city of Saint-Marc and its rural rice-farming districts located along the banks of the Artibonite River. As a student of medicine and anthropology, Koski-Karell studied water consumption and contamination, bought water and planted rice, interviewed clinicians and entrepreneurs, and observed water businesses and cholera treatment centers. Using multiple methods grounded in an ethnographic approach, Koski-Karell conducted formal and informal interviews with 90 adult participants; trained and worked with a local research assistant to study household water consumption in 50 homes across urban and rural Saint-Marc; recruited 20 adults (10 urban and 10 rural) to participate in a week-long Photovoice study; tested 10 urban and 10 rural drinking-water sources for the presence of coliform bacteria; and conducted archival research in the digital collections of the John Carter Brown Library and the Radio Haiti Archive on the history of drinking-water consumption, water privatization, water commodification, and waterborne disease in Haiti.

 

Drawing inspiration from both the arts and sciences and learning through multiple practices of knowing, our project works across genres of observation and narrative and advances new forms of knowledge, theory, research, and methods both in its principal disciplinary fields—of medical anthropology, political ecology, global health, and science and technology studies (STS)—and beyond. In Haiti, dlo se lavi (water is life); but water is also deep, fon, and its depths convey overlapping processes and meanings saturated with physical and mystical, present and historical, deadly and life-giving value. By tracing where and how cholera prompts a reorganization of water’s multiplicity of value in Haiti, we take on but move beyond a poststructuralist analysis to attend to water’s deep permeation of social and cultural life, mediated by emotion. As a more-than-human ethnography of global health, our project explores how the multi-species entanglements of humans and V. cholerae—situated in their shared waters—problematizes universalist global health knowledge of and practices around drinking-water. Integrating the anthropology of water and global health with STS, this project offers theoretical and empirical insights into how waterborne pathogens like cholera highlight the webs of histories and bodies from which all life, including human life, emerges and adjusts.

 

Beyond the bounds of science, technology, and the academic world, results from this project are likely to make an impact on how people recognize and understand the relationship among humans, cholera, and the water that links them. This project contributes to a more expansive understanding of health, wellbeing, and care, unsettling assumptions that center humans without considering the context of ecological and multispecies relationships within which they are situated and which they embody. All life emerges from, adjusts, and eventually ends in webs of histories, bodies, and materials. By expanding knowledge of the lively and deadly entanglements of humans and nonhumans such as V. cholerae and bottled water, more-than-human ethnographies like our project can make an impact on global health collaborations attempting to respond to outbreaks of waterborne disease worldwide. Our research into the ways cholera transforms both humans and water can help to improve global health practices and policies by contributing a more nuanced understanding of the ways people in Haiti invest in their own adjustments to cholera’s presence in their environment. Through its research into and critical analysis of the history of Haiti’s cholera epidemic using methods like Photovoice, this project also brings greater public awareness to the social, economic, and environmental conditions and international dynamics of coloniality and antiblackness that led to and sustained the outbreak. Results from this project may help communities and individuals advocating for structural changes to improve the lives and wellbeing of Haiti’s most vulnerable and for reparations for the injustices of the cholera epidemic.
